Topic.Title: Out of the group I worked in (as a contractor)

Message.Msg: I joined Intel in 1990 and at that time the divorce rate among Intel employees was around 35%. I spent the last 22 years there before retiring, and from my perspective this rate has not gone down. It has been a financially rewarding place to have worked, however it definitely takes its toll on ones central nervous system.

Message.Title: Intel will agree to fab arm chips using 2 process node behind technology
Message.Msg: This is how Intel will use their fabs in 2014: 14nm for high end CPUs (Broadwell) 22nm for new Atom for smartphones (Bay Trail) 32nm for fabbing arm 32nm will still be on par with TSMC's 28nm. TSMC will be stuck at planar process for a loooong time.

Topic.Title: Promising new PC experiences, AMD launches its Richland combo graphics-microprocessor chips

Message.Msg: The only benchmark results that I can find so far is a 3DMark comparing an i7-3520M, i5-3210M and i3-3110M. No system configurations and the test were run by the AMD Performance Lab. "3DMark 11 Video Card Benchmark for Windows 7 PC 3DMark 11 is the latest version of the world’s most popular benchmark. Designed to measure your PC’s gaming performance 3DMark 11 makes extensive use of all the new features in DirectX 11 including tessellation, compute shaders and multi-threading. Trusted by gamers worldwide to give accurate and unbiased results, 3DMark 11 is the best way to consistently and reliably test DirectX 11 under game-like loads. " "Let's deal with Richland's hardware performance claims first, which are detailed in the slide deck above and include the obligatory "vs. Intel" comparisons that we've learned to treat with some caution. The top-end quad-core A10-5750M is claimed to beat a laptop Core i7 by over 50 percent in terms of 3DMark performance, and even a dual-core A6-5350M is said to have a 20 percent advantage. There's no sign of any all-round computing benchmarks, however, or even real-world gaming frame rate comparisons, so we'll wait to round up reviews of the new chips before making any judgement."

Topic.Title: Talk of the Day -- TSMC, Samsung, Intel to share Apple's A7 orders

Message.Msg: Thanks. IMO, the semi-conductor cycle should run bullish for the next few years. Cloud, more compelling connectivity options, UC and big data should drive revenues for all players, with Intel's technology (14nm) leading the group. Critical for them will be capacity utilization as it affects the fixed cost component of gross margin played against ASPs to fill the plants. I suspect that being two to three years ahead on innovation should offer both a cost and a price cushion, depending upon yields. Could be quite an adventure to follow as a long.

Topic.Title: Intel Headlines

Message.Msg: "Why waste so much time on speculative rumors when there are so many more positive events that actually are happening?" [Because I believe that it's useful to figure out what's happening before it happens and frankly I think it's fun to speculate. There are so many major forces in play and I find the possibilities to be rather fascinating. Sitting back and waiting for it all to show up in the press is deadly dull. I think the moves in the foundry areas might be quite meaningful. Below is a third party opinion.] ["Respected analyst Gary Smith added: "This is very bad news for the big commercial fabs. Fpgas are the high volume, high margin cash cow designs that keep the line full and steady money coming in. This new Altera 14nm deal is the Intel foundry scooping up the gravy dollars away from TSMC." "]

Topic.Title: Intel Headlines

Message.Msg: While TSMC will still have lead customers for its yet to be announced 14nm process, the loss of Altera will be significant. Apart from the volume – and hence revenue – implications, fpga manufacture is an important part of the ramping process for new processes. TSMC has experienced well documented problems in manufacturing 28nm chips – even with the help of Altera and Xilinx. The loss of Altera – at least for the 14nm node – won't help the foundry giant. But how might this affect the 'balance of power' between Altera and Xilinx? Both make strenuous efforts to get leading edge chips out ahead of each other. The reason? Their major customers are comms companies desperate to keep ahead of the rapidly moving market. If Altera can get 14nm chips into customers' hands before Xilinx, it could get a significant advantage. Cooley believes Altera may get 14nm samples by the end of 2013. "With 14nm silicon," he concluded, "Altera will get to leapfrog Xilinx, which will be stuck in TSMC at 20nm."

Message.Title: Apple sues Samsung again
Message.Msg: [Who is the big beneficiary of ARM's biggest players beating each other bloody? Intel, of course...] Last time worked so well After Apple largely failed to meet any objective in its patent war with Samsung, the outfit is back at it with yet another court case. The new law suit is about the latest batch of Samsung products which Apple claims nicked its ideas. US District Judge Lucy Koh asked both parties what they think about the idea of staying the new lawsuit while the first case goes up on appeal, but Apple wanted to open the new case. Apple said that any delay would "seriously and irreparably prejudice Apple,” cause a long-term loss of market share and of downstream sales and loads of small fluffy animals would die if the case did not go ahead. It claims that this case is different because Samsung has made different products and Apple will have to troll with a different set of patents. Apparently this case is about newer phones like the Galaxy S III and iPhone 5. However Samsung pointed out that Apple is likely to use some of the same trial tactics that shouldn't have been allowed in the first case and are now up on appeal. Judge Koh issued a short order (PDF) stating simply, "In light of the parties’ joint status report, the Court will not stay the case." She also reiterated her earlier instructions to significantly narrow the claims in the case. The new lawsuit is still scheduled for trial in 2014. Looks like Apple trollage will go on for years without managing to stop Samsung. From Fudzilla

Message.Title: More Intel chips for ZTE
Message.Msg: Chinese can’t get enough of them ZTE is signing up for more of Intel’s Atom Z2580 processors, according to QQ Tech. Apparently the Chinese cannot get enough of Intel's new hyperthreading, dual-core processor which they think will double computer performance, triple in graphic performance while still maintaining a competitive battery life. ZTE and Intel have been getting closer since the Chinese outfit started expanding in the European market. Grand X IN, ZTE's first phone with an Intel chip, was the best selling Android phone in Austria. The model is also available in other EU countries such as Germany, Poland, Hungary, Romania, Greece, Sweden, and Norway, among others. Working with ZTE helped Intel get its foot in the door with smartphones. It has also given Chipzilla a fairly ready market. From Fudzilla [Meanwhile the shyster shills poo-poo a deal with one of the global top five smartphone manufacturers because it produced a best selling phone in mere Austria. Don't make me send Arnold over to kick your rear ends...]

Topic.Title: Another Bad Day for the ARM Technicals

Message.Msg: Well, I think the "ARM Bubble" will pop on a number of factors: - Intel taking market share in tablets/phones (should be clear by year end) - Smartphone growth slowing during 2013 to levels well below what the giddy folks are projecting (notice how HTC is sort of imploding despite operating in this "growth" segment)? - The growth that does happen will be at such low ASP levels, which will significantly mitigate the potential for a richer mix in royalty revenues beyond 2013. - Wafer costs @ fabs will go up, which will make the fabless model for many of the cheap Asian cos simply impractical. In short, owning your own fabs for this is going to be critical going forward if you don't have some sort of other competitive advantage. This is where Intel will be able to make significant inroads, since it has the best cost structure possible.

Message.Title: PCMag: Could Next Wave of iPhones and iPads Have Intel Inside?
Message.Msg: [Here you have it. The case for Apple to make an incremental move to Intel and use it to pave the way to the big move to Intel...] Does this mean x86-based chips will finally find a place inside Apple's best-selling iDevices? The short answer is an emphatic "no," at least in the near future. Rather than a move to the Intel architecture akin to Apple's sea-changing switch from IBM PowerPC chips to x86 for its MacIntosh products in 2005-06, this rumored move would utilize Intel's foundry services to produce some 10 percent of Apple's future A7 System-on-a-Chip (SoC) parts, according to DigiTimes. Those SoCs would presumably still be based on the ARM architecture, especially given Apple's major investments in the architecture, both materially and in terms of an evolved app ecosystem built around ARM. Further on down the road, say a few years out, is anybody's guess. Intel has arguably been making major strides in catching up to ARM in terms of producing competitive Atom-branded x86 processors for smartphones and tablets, which provide the kind of battery life bang mobile device makers value. Such a move would make sense for Apple, particularly as Intel paves the way for a new semiconductor manufacturing process at the 14-nanometer node, according to Patrick Moorhead, lead analyst for Moor Insights & Strategy. "Apple needs Intel's manufacturing capabilities if it hopes to maintain its position in the marketplace," Moorhead said. "Many more competitors like Samsung and Huawei are now designing their own SoCs, and in Samsung's case, manufacturing them. This mitigates Apple's design advantage and they now need something different to be competitive and that 'something' is Intel's 14-nm capabilities." "It would make perfect sense to see a 22nm 'pipe-cleaner' prior to 14nm parts. This mitigates TSMC risk and gets them ready for 14nm volume production," he said.

Message.Title: EZCH, Netronome and Intel Foundry
Message.Msg: [It's reports like these that provide compelling evidence that the tipping point has been reached in regard to Intel's fabrication, technology and manufacturing...] On the other hand, EZCH's foundry provider Taiwan Semiconductor will fabricate the supposedly next-generation NP-5 at only a 28nm scale. A smaller manufacturing scale can increase energy efficiency and add to bandwidth capacity. As a private company, Netronome has been under-covered by equity analysts and we believe that EZCH investors are underestimating the risks imposed by this formidable competitor. The significance of the Intel foundry relationship may be confirmed as Cisco is rumored to be near announcing a billion dollar foundry deal with Intel to produce its own silicon chips. If this were the case, it would prove that Cisco clearly values Intel's 22nm-scale technology. From Kerrisdale Capital

Topic.Title: Intel Lenovo Sleeper Hit

Message.Msg: Lenovo's K900 smartphone might just be a sleeper hit, not just for its great internal specs, but for its price. Internally, we should expect a 5.5-inch 1080p display baked into a nice and slim 6.9mm profile, inside we'll find an Intel Atom processor clocked at 2GHz.

Topic.Title: PCMag: Could Next Wave of iPhones and iPads Have Intel Inside?

Message.Msg: For any deal to work it must benefit both parties. The only party this idea benefits is Apple. Intel just needs to maintain its relentless product improvement schedule and wait about a year. By mid 2014 Haswell chips will be powering the best performing and most desirable workstations, desktops, ultrabooks and tablets and Atom will be powering the best performing smartphones. Vendors of ARM-based hardware will be find themselves falling further and further behind Intel-based vendors and the tone of the discussion will be very different then. We won't be having this discussion about Intel making a measely 10% of Apple's ARM junk, it will be a discussion how Apple remains relevent in a world where the leading vendors have a uniform instruction set, OS kernel, and software development environment across their entire product line and Apple is still struggling to unify its desktop and laptops with its mobile business.

Message.Msg: Android tablets to outsell iPads. "IDC today revised its forecasts for the tablet market through 2013, which it now believes will climb to 190.9 million total units shipped. By the end of the year, IDC predicts that more Android tablets will be shipped than iPads for the first time since the iPad's 2010 debut."

Topic.Title: Android Tablets Pushing Aside iPad: IDC

Message.Msg: Intel will be in plenty of Android tablets soon.

Topic.Title: PCMag: Could Next Wave of iPhones and iPads Have Intel Inside?

Message.Msg: Agree, the advances in Intel far outweigh Arm, Apple needs to distansance itself from the Samsung clone. Arm camp is suddenly sinlent with respect to the power advantage myth, arm processors have over intel. Already on the 32nm process Intel Atom is comparable power consumption with ARM's latest and greatest. Problem Apple faces is that unless their next MacBook has touch screen capability, it simply wont be desirable as opposed with Ultrabook touchscreens. Likewise a MacTouch convertable will canabilise Apples own Tablet market. Why buy a iTab able to run RISC apps only when you can buy a MacTouch with more processing capability, legeacy apps (X86+RISC), and doubles as a Tablet? Likewise, iPhone-x86 is the smarter progression for Apple.Why buy a iPhone able to run only RISC apps, when you can buy a iPhone-x86 with more processing capability, legeacy apps (X86+RISC), and distances itself from the Samsung clone. Most valuable asset Apple have is their product appeal and OS. Though even hard core Apple fans will swith to alternative products which have higher specs. Ok, Apples investment in their own ARM designs is significant, though lets realise they have had a huge return on this investment. Simply put Apple needs Intels far more than Intel needs Apple. Technology and feature is the key, and Intel can deliver. ARM is limited, and by it's architecture will remain limited. look at WinRT as a classic example of ARM failure. Surely Apple aren't so nieve to believe they can survive on a lesser technology and expect growth.

Topic.Title: Android Tablets Pushing Aside iPad: IDC

Message.Msg: If one spends the money on a good tablet with a high quality display and generous storage they should get a lot of utility from it. Consumers shouldn't be limited to just one OS. Bascially that's a closed box. Tablets that use Core architecure or Atom can run full W8 and can potentially multi-boot Android, Ubuntu Touch, and Tizen. I would readily pay the money for an mSATA SSD large enough (say 256GB) to be able to multi-boot whatever OS I need at the time. This would also help prevent premature obsolescence of one's purchase.

Topic.Title: Intel has mobile under control

Message.Msg: Clover.. has half the battery life of the Snapdragon. In mobile people choose battery life over performance.

Message.Title: Intel releases Android Jelly Bean 4.2.2 dev code, adds dual-boot option for Windows 8
Message.Msg: Intel is OS-independent...with work with all major OSes - Windows/Mac/Linux/Chrome

Topic.Title: Intel has mobile under control

Message.Msg: do you have anything to back this claim? link?

Topic.Title: Intel has mobile under control

Message.Msg: That's my estimate based on knowledge of CloverTrail battery life and Snapdragon and the changes since for both chips. Note that for Clover, you have to add the battery drain of the Baseband chip which is not integrated like the Snapdragon 600.

Topic.Title: Intel has mobile under control

Message.Msg: It's just another made up lie from the ARMH shareholder who likes to come here and spread his FUD. Razr-I vs Razr-M shows how this comparison will work out as the cores will be equally doubled on both sides.
